product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: TexARC, aka A.Ron Carmichael
content: 30 feet and one hollow wooden wall between router wifi and the door, the audio is completely unintelligible and video breaks up.  Two Nest cameras even further away and multiple walls and floor, stream video HD quality.  Linking with either laptop or cell phone app is slow and hit-or-miss.  Wish I had returned this 4 days ago when I still could.  The battery inside does not charge from the 12v transformer that drives the original door bell, you have to take it out and charge it ike a cell phone.  Hard to do from 3 hours drive away.  Motion detector works, but by the time I can get the app to link, the person has long gone.  argh.
title: Not something I would buy again.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: JD Droddy
content: I waited for awhile before writing this review to be sure that I really understood the pros and cons.  Based on some of the other reviews, I was a bit skeptical.  As it turns out, I really love this product.  Many of the negatives I heard about seemed to me to be caused by not having sufficient Wi-Fi signal.  ' When I purchased the product, I thought I had a hard-wired doorbell in place.  It turned out to be a battery operated remote.  So, I installed the system as a battery operated unit.  I discovered that the battery would drain faster than I chose to fool with, so I purchased the solar operated charging sleeve.  I had to buy it from the factory ($49), as it was not available from Amazon.  That was much cheaper than having an electrician come install the necessary wiring.  I'm pleased to say that the charger works  very well and the unit stays at 100 percent most of the time.  It drops a bit after two or three days of cloudy weather, but has never gone below 94 percent. It took a bit to adjust the zones to the point that I didn't get excessive false alarms from passing traffic.  I occasionally get one now when a large vehicle passes on our side of the street, but they are relatively rare  and not significant considering the stability.  The unit had only been installed a few days when our doorbell went off at 2:00 a.m.  From my bedroom, I was able to determine that the ringer was a mentally ill person who lives in the neighborhood and has been reported by others as ringing the doorbell in the middle of the night.  I monitored the situation until the person went away, without having to open the door. I highly recommend this product if you have a good Wi-Fi signal at your door.  If you don't, you might be disappointed.  BTW, the $30 per year subscription comes to about 8 cents per day.  This is certainly a small price to pay for having all incidents recorded and downloadable if necessary.
title: Works as Advertised if you have good wi-fi -- Recommend Solar Charger if you don't have hard wiring available

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: She
content: Just bought this device less than 1 week ago and I am ready to return it. Worked okay for less than 1 day then stopped working. It wasn't showing the live stream at all just hours after set up. I uninstalled the app and reinstalled like instructed and still I'm having issues. I unattached the device and decided to start over, but now the ring won't even connect to my router at all! It's not even showing the router as an option most of the time. My internet works great and I have great speed. My modem and router are both brand new (purchased and set up at the same time as the ring) and built for high power gaming and streaming. There is currently only 5 devices connected to my router (for 2 people) so I know it is not being overused. I've called customer service and followed instruction and still not working. This item is trash and I will be returning it today. So sad because I was very excited, but I chose to ignore all the negative comment and give it a try so this is what I get. Not worth my time and money. Also, the few hours the device did work, it wasn't picking up motion until I was directly in front the device, but later at night, it started picking up cars driving by that are much farther away than my lawn. 😒 Wow. This item is a great concept, but the overall mechanics needs more work. And for the cost we pay, these issues should not be so prevelant this long after the initial product was launched. So disappointed 😔
title: Don't waste your time

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Maxwells
content: Everything about this is a 5 star device except for one thing. They either purposefully or ignorantly made the wifi receiver incredibly inefficient. They basically make it so you have to buy the stupid Chime Pro to be able for it to function. Before we got the Chime, the video would play 3 seconds, freeze for 5 seconds, play for 3, etc. Useless if you're trying to use this for security. It sits a measured 22 feet from my high-powered gaming router, WELL within what they describe as acceptable distance to receive a "very good" signal. The infuriating part is when I bought the Ring I also bought a regular non-antennae Chime to put by our bedroom. So now I have one useless Chime and a Chime Pro I shouldn't have needed, on top of a $200 doorbell. But yea... beyond that, it's great. After the stupid Chime Pro, video is very quick and the quality is great, the app is great, the notifications it sends you are instant and the live feed is a great touch. Before the Pro, it would send me notifications 5-30 minutes after the ring, live video wouldn't connect, let alone doorbell ring videos. Just do yourself a favor and incorporate another 50 bucks into budgeting for one of these.
title: Useless without the stupid Chime Pro

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Cliff
content: I love it. I have a really weak, at the front door, wifi signal. I hope the extender will help when arrives. That being said, every time there is motion on the porch I get a notification wherever I am and can access the video and audio. My only issue and I will update,  is access to Live view is sporadic. I'm almost positive it is because the signal strength is poor. 30 bucks a year for the basic service is doable for me, and as much Amazon as I do, could pay for itself. It works, but be ready to relocate your wireless router or use an extender. I agree with another review that the packaging is super and everything you need is there, though I found a cordless drill helpful. I particularly liked the remark to put the n/a hardware in that drawer with all the stuff you'll never use. I called with some questions. Either I. got lucky or these people know about what they are selling and have an appropriate personality to assist. Got the Chime pro. All is well now, . Very nice. more later.
title: A good investment, in my view.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Lindy
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Revised opinion of doorbell: once you get past the setup, it works like nobody's business! Update: See the video. It looks as if these two are dressed as plumbers but the only tool they carry is a drill. They wear black rubber gloves because California this time of year is so breezy.  I ran this by three expert opinions. 1 - a plumber)  No tool belts, no tools except for the drill, no holster for the drill. These are burglars not plumbers 2 - the cops) Every detail is consistent with burglary. Do not treat this as a joke or prank. 3 - Ring customer service)  The video and audio are coming out great! Those are burglars. I called the plumbing company. Yes they had staff on the job at my location that day. But, it was an outside line that needed work. The only reason for anyone to knock on a door would be to get access to a power line. No electrical extension cords on these two. I conclude this plumbing company has a criminal ring inside of it. The cover story is they are just a bunch of jokers. Management is not clueless but they are afraid of going out of business and unable to handle the situation. Out of some sense of kindness to the company, I've withheld the name, BUT they are located in the Bay Area. If you are a local resident and would like to follow through contact me directly lindy.cheng@gmail.com Moral of the story: I went and purchased two Ring Security Cameras. One for each bozo. End update I had my troubles getting the Ring Video Doorbell to run smoothly. I finally traced my troubles to my VPN. Shut down your VPN and the setup goes smoothly (more or less). Next when I went to mount the doorbell, the only bolts that fit were too short to reach the mounting bracket.  So, i put the video doorbell in the closet, and by pure luck aimed it at the door handle for the front door.  It stayed there for over a week. During the week, I managed to cry a bunch on Peter's shoulder, Ring's Customer Service Angel.  Because during all these weeks of trying to set up Ring, the O-Beast, my very own personal stalker had tried to break in twice (that I could detect) and the stress had gotten to me.  The truth is, by the time Peter appeared to fix things, the equipment was  WORKING but I was so stressed out I couldn't figure out simple things  - like how to mount the Ring Video doorbell without the correct bolts. Peter got to work and did he pull off a doozy. He set up an more advanced configuration of sensors so I could keep windows open. With so many sensors, the software can't keep up with all the possibilities! But the new versions are coming!  Even limited to current software, the option to keep window and patio doors cracked open but alarmed has made a huge difference in livability. But here's the big one: I had completely forgotten about my smoke & carbon monoxide detector. It was old and needed replacing.  It didn't occur to me my O-Beast might try and set the place on fire. Since many of my evening medications are sedatives this kind of attack means CERTAIN DEATH. I would die of smoke inhalation before I woke up.  But the Ring fire alarms goes straight to the fire station. May I respectfully advise everyone who uses sedative medications to PLEASE GET AN ALARM that ALERTS the FIRe DEPARTMENT DIRECTLY!!! You don't want to wake up dead. Meanwhile, forgotten in the closet the Ring doorbell had dutifully recorded my passing feet...exits/entry. And two mysterious events. At 1:30 AM  and then at 5 AM on two very different days, something triggered the Ring doorbell and it recorded something for over two minutes each time. Unfortunately, the resolution is too low (it's near pitch dark) and the audio pickup too faint.  There are no other incidents which occur this late at night. My best guess, there is PLENTY of other evidence which shows someone has been trying to pick my lock using the credit card method. My previous doorknob was worn down useless, my weatherstripping around the locks *only* was in tatters.  In fact, I listened to her do this for one night but she ran too quickly for me to wake up enough to do anything sensible like chase after her. Even though I only put it up today (I decided to skip the "right" equipment and just use JB Weld Steelstik - metal epoxy).  The camera has been working great on everyday tests. I suspect I'll have results before the week is out. Update, Sept. 2, 2018 The Treasure Truck is a great deal! But it sure don't give you time to research before you're forced to make a buy decision. About Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI) - the RSSI number indicates the strength of a wireless signal with zero being perfect and -100 worthless.  If you routinely experience trouble viewing video,  since the Ring video is HD, you need a better signal. Signs of bad signal, B&W video in daylight,  you get motion detection but the video hesitates and may not turn on all. The reason why my wireless signal is pathetic is because I live in Silicon Valley in a huge apartment complex. Everyone has souped up wireless except me. First - download a wireless analyser app and check your environment. 15 or so wireless networks with stronger signals than yours is bad news. Second - move your router closer to the video doorbell. It's worth  trying. Third - The Ring video doorbell will alert the app but it won't alert the base station. You may want a Ring Chime or Chime Pro. The Chime Pro will extend the wireless signal while chiming every time the video doorbell gives the alert. The  doorbell operates much more like a doorbell. Finally, Costco has their usual get-a-deal-if-you-buy-the-economy size on Ring security devices. I found the prices fair but the packages were much more thoughtfully sized for a small apartment. It comes with equipment that I wasn't sure was necessary but I'm discovering is essential. Update: Dec. 2018  Sometimes old-fashioned is as good as anything It looks like the O-Beast is up and raring to go for the holiday season. On Thanksgiving day roundabouts dinner time and 11:30 PM.  I got home, dis-armed the Ring alarm to enter. Then when I tried to re-arm it, it kept telling me "a sensor is out of place". One by one I checked my two windows and two doors. I tracked it down to one window in particular. It was less than 1/4" out of place.  The window had not opened any further because I'd cut wooden dowels to fit when I moved in.  This was enough to break sensor contact but not enough to trigger the alarm; it takes 1/2" of movement to get the alarm. Sigh, my windows are two stories up. At this, I was afflicted with a vision of the O-Beast up precariously, over 200 lbs of suet flapping in the breeze trying to break in.  TMD. I would pay money to erase that. I checked the windows again. The one with the dis-placed sensor had a strangely clean fly-screen. The window that read OK was just plain dirty with fierce dust bunnies defending it still. Huh. Too bad, the O-Beast hadn't cleaned the windows. I might have some forgiveness. Why, oh why hadn't I put cameras on the windows? Once you start putting up videocameras on your wireless network, you quickly realize that most routers can't handle it.  Not only did I need a router that could push signal out far but it needs to handle large volumes of HD quality video. I was getting garbage when I tried to put cameras on the windows. I wrote a really long email to Peter, my Ring Customer Service Angel describing the problem and he wrote an treatise on how to handle wireless for Ring. Option 1) I can stick with the mandatory AT & T router and daisy-chain Chime Pros all the way out to the bedrooms. I guesstimate it would take 3  Chime Pros to throw the wireless out that far. This doesn't handle the AT&T routers issues with massive amounts of data.  At Blk Friday prices, that would have been $150 Option 2) Get a better router: Peter recommended the Netgear Orbi's (high end solution) or the Netgear Nighthawk Dual Band series (lower cost solution).  Both effective with Ring devices. I ended up going with the Orbi because 1) my TV is about 5' away from the AT&T router and has trouble picking up the signal and 2) I ran into the Orbi RBK40  Blk Friday sale price ($200) and I just fell in love...with the specs, yah, ya. That's right, it was a cold decision based purely on performance (and looks and price. I'm just a calculatin machine I am.).  Plus, it's not real clear that I'm done adding videocamera's to Ring.  Higher end is safer for me. Now, after Orbi, the RSSI signals from the video doorbells and cameras at the window are SWEET (RSSI's all around 30-ish) and.... I ordered two more video cameras from Ring. Why two more? One for my window w/o a camera and one for my door where I already have a video doorbell. Huh? The kind policeman explained it (yes, I have been known to roam the landscape searching for answers): The two cameras protect each other.  Mount them so each camera sees the other. When the crook tries to take out the first camera you have 1) evidence that a crime was committed, 2) enough $$$ damage that they can be prosecuted for something meaningful and put away and 3) Ring has a warranty on the video equipment. If the cameras are stolen (must file a police report) and if you get the 1-year protection plan ($100)  then they will replace the stolen equipment. And yeah, Ring just announced their series of *indoor* cameras. Sigh. Just as soon as I finish the outer Ring camera system, I'll have to think about the indoor Ring of cameras. I sure hope I don't need more Orbi satellites.... Did I forget to mention that? The base Orbi system can be extended beyond it's original 5000 sq ft  specs.... And since the Ring system can support up to 99 devices... I can probably get signal out to my car. On the freeway. Don't laugh. The O-Beast will trash my car if she thinks she can't get to me.  This is the next logical step after the windows/patio door are denied her. Luckily, she thinks she's a suuu-per geN-iUs.  That's right. She thinks...  I'm dinner? I guess, she never actually paid attention to that show? Gotta go build my Acme Beastie-Blaster specially designed for our automobile lifestyle. Beep-beep. Remember the value of autos is automatically high enough to put her away. I just need a camera that can take video in all directions at once....
title: Detected the stalker from behind a locked door and caught these two

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Sandra Johnson
content: So I installed my new Ring Doorbell 2 today and tried to wire it where the old doorbell was but no go. I tested the wires but they are dead and I don't know why. The doorbell always worked before but whatever. No big deal. After some frustrating time which felt like an eternity I finally got the Ring device to work. It wasn't the device it was my WiFi connection but I didn't realize it until two hours into this process. The device works fine and the image is very clear during the day. It's night time now and I just checked it. Wow. Looks like daytime out there. I'm very impressed with this device so far. I don't get many visitors but I live on a busy avenue near a high school and there is sometimes a lot of sidewalk traffic. Also, earlier this year my mailbox was stolen and the thief even left his or her gloves on the sidewalk. The police didn't do anything about it because they said it was a petty crime. Maybe if the mailbox was full of donuts they would have tried to find it. Anyway, the Ring Doorbell 2 is pretty neat. It's my first security device and I might even get one for my backdoor. I think you will be pleased if you get one of these devices. I'm a woman and live alone and if I can install this thing so can you. The box comes with everything you need to install this device but I used one of my own screwdrivers for the concrete screws. Had to put some oomph into it. Now all I need is for someone to come to the door to test it out. Oh I want to add that I would have given this five stars but the sound quality isn't very good. When I tested the device (several times) I spoke into it or at it from various distances. Even at very close range the sound isn't good. It's especially not very good because of the traffic going by. I could hear that quite well unfortunately. My voice sounded far away and like I was speaking into a tin can. Update Dec.16: So I was going to buy another Ring Doorbell 2 and see that it is now $169. I paid $118 for mine. Why the jump in price???
title: Who's There? Ring knows!

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Customer8284
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Great concept, but the device itself fails to deliver.  Specifically, the motion sensor is inconsistent.  It triggers when a car is passing by, yet it periodically fails to trigger when someone is approaching my house.  The recording would show a person walking away from my house, but it didn't start recording the approach. Very disappointing.  Also, the video quality is fairly poor.  The device itself feels very cheap. Finally, the mounting is poorly designed.  There are no mounting holes at the top of the device, which creates a small gap between the wall and the ring doorbell.  It looks bad, and make is fairly easy for someone to just rip the device out.
title: Great concept, but the device itself fails to deliver

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: M. N.
content: UPDATE : Through a series of updates, the doorbell speaker volume is now so low I can't actually interact with anyone ringing the doorbell because they can't hear I word I say. I have finally reached wit's end after owning this doorbell for an entire year. Let's be clear, if someone rings the bell, you'll get notified. If a solicitor is standing in front of your door, observing everything around the front of your home within eyesight, you'll be notified after they've had their fill and are leaving. The bottom line is the motion detection on this product is absolute garbage. Speaking of garbage, it'll detect motion when the weekly garbage truck goes by, but not when a persistent roofer comes onto my property to leave solicitations on my door. It'll detect motion when the daily schoolbus goes by, but not when fedex runs over my mailbox. Make no mistake, I have opened many service tickets to address the issue, but it's the same run around every time. "let's try a factory reset" is always going to be the response no matter the issue or how many times you call. I have installed the included directional wedges in the hopes of getting a better experience. No such luck. Pass on ring guys. It's owned by Amazon now so it'll only get worse.
title: Wonderful doorbell, if you like delayed response

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Totally Graphic (Consignment)
content: It's not often I will take the time to write reviews. In this case one is needed to save others from this purchasing mistake. The neither the motion detection or doorbell worked as seen in their ads. Both worked some of the time if at all. Ring 2 is a product with potential, maybe in another 2-5 years it might finally work as advertised (Like Dial-Up vs Fiber) I watched all the YouTube videos on using Ring 2 and I saw the happy people but I think that's a very small part of the product's story. Most of the people who ran into problem probably just gave up and didn't even bother to waste more time writing a review. If you do decide to buy any Ring doorbell. TEST IT BEFORE MOUNTING!* First check your internet speed. How old is your Router? 3 years or older, you might need a new one. Stand  out side of your home with Ring in one hand and your phone in the other. Ring it. Try the motion detection. Repeat this indoors, repeat again right next to your wifi router. If it works for you then you are one of the lucky few. My bet, by the time you've done the outdoor test you'll be ready for a refund. Ring 2 is a great product idea, it's just not ready yet for wide public use. Give it a few more years. * There's a YouTube video of some guy who purchased and mounted a Ring Pro on a $2000 custom door. He is not happy!
title: DOES NOT WORK AS ADVERTISED!

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Jeffrey
content: My first ring installed easily. Worked fine for about a year, then disconnected. Tech support helped to get it back on my network, then it failed about 30 days later. After spending quite a bit of time on this, upgrading to the new Ring doorbell, I did get things working. There was a major effort by tech support in getting me a new unit and hanging in there to insure success. While my wifi network shouldn't have been at fault, there was something about my network that caused problems. The fix was reverting to the built in wifi in my Comcast router instead of my Ubiquiti WAP behind the firewall. Who'd have thought? Chances are an "average" network environment would work better. Maybe it was my firewall? Kudos to tech support who went above and beyond to earn 5+ stars, but I had to give 4 for the amount of time I spent.
title: It's a cool device that does a lot.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: DiscerningTaste
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. I don’t normally take the time to write product reviews. Amazon is great at taking things back when they don’t work. This however is so enraging that I feel it necessary to inform everyone of the fraud that Ring is perpetuating upon society. First, let me say that if you’re looking for a video doorbell, I assume it will do the trick, though the slow speed and lag time between ring and video connection makes it useless for anything except someone sitting and waiting at the door. The real failure of this device is its “motion detection”. To illustrate, I’ve attached photos and video. It goes off about every 5 minutes (leaving battery life that lasts 3 days), even for things across the street, even though it’s supposed to have a 5’ range (also attached). The kicker is that it Doesn’t actually catch people coming up to the door. It only shows me coming in our out about 1 in 10 times. title: One of the worst products I’ve ever seen

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Particular person
content: Here is some of the information I was looking for before I purchased this Ring Video Doorbell 2.  So far it has exceeded my expectations. This doorbell records for about 30 sec and is activated in one of three ways: by pressing the ring button, having motion, or pressing "live view" from your phone.  It stores this video to a Ring Cloud using a good WiFi connection to the device.  From the Ring app on my iphone I can select any one of these videos to see.  My wife's phone was set up as a shared user so she can see the videos also, from anywhere there is WiFi or a good cellular connection.  My minipad has the Ring app so it gets all the same information my iphone gets.  My iphone or minipad can delete files, but my wife's phone can't (I assume because she is a shared user.) All of these devices can hear and speak to the ring doorbell when activated. This model uses existing 12 v AC wires from the old doorbell transformer.  This keeps the battery charged and pressing the Ring door bell also activates my house door bell just as the old button did. The motion sensor  always activates before anyone can get close enough to push the doorbell.  I can set the radius of sensing somewhere between 6 ft to 30 ft.  About 15 ft has worked well so far.  In addition there are pie-shaped motion sensing zones.  My door bell is corner mounted with one vertical wedge to aim the camera more towards the front.  Because of this aim direction, one motion zone closest to the corner was set inactive. It will pick up night images from near total darkness,  but images are not as good as in daylight.  Camera was mounted 48 inches high as recommended.  Try to avoid light sources that might shine directly into the camera if you want highest quality images.  I plan to add the Ring Cloud package for $3 per month that lets my images stay stored for a month or so. If you are away from home and not in a good WiFi zone, I think obtaining a immediate live image would be difficult.  However, if a live image was previously stored, you would probably be able to view it with a good cellular connection. I installed the doorbell one week ago and so far It has worked very well.
title: Summary of some useful user questions

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: M. Moss
content: This is practically unusable for home security. I have family that sing Ring's praises, so I was shocked at how bad the Ring 2 was. I had it hardwired with a strong wifi signal, and had the following issues: 1. The doorbell is in a shaded alcove, so anything outside the alcove / in sunlight is completely washed out and unidentifiable 2. While on cell connection, my phone has worse then even odds of being able to connect for live view, and doesn't provide an error message beyond 'we're having trouble reaching the servers'... despite the fact the servers just told me about motion detected. 3. This wouldn't be as big an issue if I could view live motion on a PC. Unfortunately, every PC I have is a windows 7 or linux machine, meaning I only have access to the web app, which can't provide live view, or do many other things. 4. Occasionally I'll attempt a live view from the cell phone, and it won't fail- but it will show nothing but a black screen. Figure, ohh, maybe this is a bad cell connection, let's see what the Ring website has recorded for the live view session.... it's a black screen. :( 5. Recording only starts 1-2 seconds after motion detected, which means for delivery folk you only see their backs, if you see anything at all 6. Motion not reliably detected, despite sensitivity being cranked up to max 7. The white ring LEDs are far too bright, they invite attention, which is the last thing I want; there's no reason that can't be disabled in settings 8. I don't know it for a fact, but I expect if internet is down or Ring servers are down, nothing will be recorded 9. I find the vendor lockin / Apple approach of "Closed hardware used the way we tell you to" annoying. I'd like to have the option of, say, uploading to a local FTP server rather then sending video to the cloud, especially if my own internet isn't great. Though I accept the DIY tech crowd isn't part of the target audience. I've switched to the Ring Pro, and most of these seem to be either resolved or at least acceptable, but the Ring 2 is unusable for security. And I don't really understand why- it was released more then a year after the Ring Pro, it's hardwired, it should be able to support basic things like a video buffer, and reasonable internet connectivity. Nice things: PIR motion sensor (probably), so things like shadows from trees blowing in the wind don't trigger a motion alarm Did come with all hardware needed, and useful extras (though the hardwire kit didn't come with anything for connecting to existing wires) It would support battery operation, so if you wanted to just duck tape it to a post in your front yard you could.
title: Not usable for home security

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Baseballman86
content: Pros: I love the concept of this product, and it is extremely useful and reassuring as a homeowner.  The design of the product is sleek and attractive and the user interface of the app is very easy to learn and navigate.  That said, this product has one annoying flaw, and it's really more of a ripoff than a flaw. Cons Once your trial of ring video recording ends, you can no longer access past events without a paid subscription.  That's not such a big deal until you realize what counts as a "recent event".  If you don't press the button within about 5 seconds of getting a motion alert, you missed your shot and now it's a past event.  Say the UPS guy comes, presses the doorbell and walks off immediately.  Your phone properly notifies you that somebody is at your door, but you've got something in your hands, or your phone is in your pocket or any other distraction is going on that takes 5 seconds to finish.  By the time you hit the notification banner and go into the app, it will take you to a screen that says you need a paid subscription to see past events.  Earlier today I got a notification WHILE holding my phone, clicked it immediately, but the live video loaded slowly and by the time it did load, the "event" was considered done and it took me to the screen saying I needed to pay.  I have no problem paying to record everything and be able to pull up events from hours, days or weeks ago, but needing to pay because 5 seconds went by and the app loaded slowly is a rip-off.  This is a $200 item which replaces a $5 hardware store doorbell, and the ONE thing it's supposed to do (show you live video of rings or motion events at your door) doesn't work about half the time without paying extra.  There needs to be about a 30 second window at minimum where you can see what's going on without having to pay extra. When I contacted customer service about this, they were friendly and helpful, but ultimately only gave me one extra month free trial, which has since expired and doesn't fix the problem.  This is a product flaw.  Be aware that if you want this to work properly, you're going to need to sign up for an ongoing subscription.  To work as advertised, this is really a $200 doorbell with a $30 yearly subscription fee.
title: I love the concept of this product

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Stephanie W
content: The doorbell works well, with some delay with loading the video and providing notifications. Had to charge the battery about every 3 weeks.. Which is annoying because you don't have a functioning doorbell during this time. I wish ring provided an extra battery with this model, as it was about 80$ more than the first model when I purchased it. With the only other upgrade being 1080p video, which isn't much different than 720p. Also in order to view any saved video captured from motion, you have to pay $30 a year. So factor that into your cost... Edit: with good signal strength and 65% battery it is unable to load live view...
title: Not worth the money

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Amy D
content: I have given this product one star because I can not give it zero stars. We had very high hopes for this product as we had heard many great things.  As I read the reviews I became a little concerned about some of the one star reviews and complaints about functionality but figured it might be attributed to bad routers, extended distances, poor signals etc.  Unfortunately this was not the case as we had none of those circumstances at our home. I will start with the good.  The item comes well packaged with excellent instructions and all of the necessary tools and hardware.  It also gives you several different manners in which to mount the unit.  We charged the battery for approximately nine (9) hours, tested the camera to ensure that it was working and had it mounted in about five (5) minutes.  So far so good.  Then we tried to test it. Our front door has a walkway that leads up to it and it is clear from obstructions for about 40 feet.  We set the Ring on the most sensitive and furthest range.  I walked at a normal pace from about 40 feet away directly to the Ring doorbell while my wife was inside with her iPhone monitoring the camera for movement and notifications. Imagine my surprise when I was standing right in front of this camera waving my hands like an idiot only to NOT have it notify my wife of anything.  Approximately five (five) minutes later, she received a notification along with a video of me walking AWAY from the Ring and my front door.  The video started when I was about 10 feet away.  (this is after having walked right up to it and waved my hands in front of it). We repeated several tests over the next two days and realize that the capabilities of this product are a far cry from what was advertised.  I'm not sure how we are supposed to have a two way conversation with anyone if we don't get notified until AFTER they leave.  On top of it all, after less than a week, the battery notified us that it needed to be recharged. In short, this product delivered NOTHING that it promised.  It's like buying a balloon that has holes in it.  You can't use it for what it was intended and that renders it useless.
title: We had very high hopes for this product as we had heard many great things. As I read the reviews I became ...

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: John Archer
content: As first-time parents, safety and security are our top concerns. This made a video doorbell very appealing to us. After a ton of research we decided the Ring Video Doorbell 2 would be the best choice. When it works, the Ring delivers decent video and audio and picks up motion without a problem. Emphasis on "when it works." Despite our internet running at 300mpbs or faster, our Ring struggles to pick up a solid signal from our router, which is no more than 15 feet from the RING. The several times I've contacted the Ring support team they've been very friendly. They even sent us a signal boosting Chime Pro for free to help with the signal problem. Unfortunately this only made the signal worse according to the support team. Because our Ring receives a poor signal from our router, it often struggles to connect - failing completely in many cases. It even fails to capture motion because of this. Even when it manages to detect motion, it often doesn't record any kind of motion event footage, as the signal was too poor. Fortunately we live in a fairly safe neighborhood, in a fairly safe town. This made it all the more upsetting when we came home to find someone's tools ON TOP of our Ring device. The person failed to detach the Ring, luckily. The real irony is that the Ring didn't even capture footage of the event due to its poor signal. Despite this, we now pay the $3 a month required to save our online footage - when it captures. We're out of the return window due to our many attempts to fix the device through Ring support. If I could do it over, I'd be tempted to send it back and try another brand. Everything else in our house gets a killer signal, so why this device can't get a signal from our router that's only 15 feet away is beyond me.
title: Great - when it works

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Michael J. McKenzie
content: I wanted to start my security with a live view camera doorbell. The Ring video doorbell 2 had great reviews, so I decided to give it a whirl. Here are the pros and cons of the Ring doorbell. My system is not a wired one so I had to use the battery pack. Ring says the batteries come between 50% and 75% charged, but I had to charge the battery overnight before I got the indicator that the battery was fully charged. The package comes with a USB to micro USB charger. Installation was pretty straightforward. Everything you should need is in the package. You may need to use a drill if you have concrete, stone, or wood backings. It comes with a handy level that you can install temporarily to ensure you get a level doorbell. It also comes with wedges if you need to angle your doorbell in a different direction. This comes in handy if you have stairs, a hill, or are close to a road. Installation probably took about 30 minutes, but hats because I had a few obstacles to overcome with my doorframe. Application installation only took a few minutes and after the software was updated (which took about 1 minute) the Ring was ready to use. If you do need to use the battery be sure to install the safety screw in the bottom. Again, the screwdriver and specialty driver come with the package. And if anyone tries to steal your Ring doorbell, Ring says they will replace it for free within the first year. Hopefully you’ll get the video of someone stealing it. For the iPhone, the app is really user friendly. It takes about 5 or so seconds to pull up the live view but every other feature is instantaneous. Adding other Ring devices is also painless and easy through the app. Another great feature is that it is Alexa capable. So depending on your preferences, you can have Alexa let you know when someone’s at the door or you can do it through the phone notification or you can do it through both. The ring doorbell 2 touts a 1080p video, but this is only if the WiFi it connects to is strong. Ring has a level system to indicate WiFi strength. -99 is the worst WiFi strength and I suppose -0 is the best. My living room is essentially in the backside of the house whereas the front door is obviously in front. When I was first installing the doorbell my wife tried the intercom system. She came through broken and choppy and it was hard to hear her. As well, the video doesn’t seem to be 1080p. The first two pics I attached are pre- Chime WiFi extender and the second set is after the WiFi extender. This increased my WiFi level from -62 to -53. I’ve tried the WiFi extender in various outlets and the results are pretty much the same. I’ll provide a review for the Chime and WiFi extender in its own area. It has made it easier to hear and speak through the two way speaker system, but the video quality is still nominal at best. A cool feature is if you use the live view system you can zoom in and out. However, if the video quality isn’t that great, you’re not getting much detail to the zoom. The Ring doorbell does have a lot of neat features like a variety of different rings. The one feature you’ll have to play with most to your preferences is the motion settings. You can increase or decrease the motion ranges as well as turning on or off 1 of 3 preset areas (left, middle, right). See pictures. I also have my live view available which Ring says depletes the battery faster. After about a week of toying around with it, the battery level dropped from 97% to 85%. So we’ll see how long this thing lasts. I’ll provide an update to the full length of battery life. After you register your device you’ll have 30 days of free subscription service. This means all the videos your Ring captures will be available to you. I’m still within the first 30 days myself, so I’m not sure if what is captured will be saved on my device or not, but I’ll post an update when that happens. On the bright side though, for only $30 a year you can pay for the subscription, which is ridiculously cheaper than other products. All in all, for the price point, features, and quality, I am giving the Ring doorbell 2 four stars. This means if I ever need to replace it, I might look somewhere else if something new comes on the market, otherwise I’ll be getting the Ring again. Update: with average usage, the battery lasted 10 weeks before needing a recharge.
title: Good device for beginner security

author: VicB
content: I wanted this product to work. I really did. Installing it to the wall was the easy part. Getting it to work? Ridiculous. I've had nothing but problems with it for months, and when I called customer service, I was on the phone for a good 35 minutes with a young man who had NO idea what he was doing, and he couldn't assist me. The final straw for me is that I had a package stolen from my front porch today, in broad daylight, and my Ring was just asleep at the wheel. Nothing. No doorbell alert, no front door activity alert recorded even though it was technically 'online.' The Ring Video Doorbell 2 has been worthless for me, and I've had it for 3 months: 1) It falls off the wifi regularly - like others, I had to purchase an extender. 2) My battery drains every 2 weeks - I finally set the perimeter so that it only records the most limited area possible. 3) Even when it's connected to the wifi, when people ring the doorbell, nothing happens on my phone, and the action recordings/alerts are even worse. It just doesn't work. It's too late for me to return this product, and I'm really annoyed about that. Especially now that I have to deal with this stolen package issue. So the least I can do is warn you to save your money and find a product that actually works.

content: Here's some advice: "Play" with the Doorbell prior to installing it.  "Play" in engineer speak means: 1. Power it up. 2. Move it throughout your home - Dark and Light filled spaces. 3. Press the Doorbell. See how fast your cell responds. 4. Look at picture Quality. Is it clear? Does the video lag behind actual movement? The Ring Doorbell fails miserably on steps 3 and 4. Slow loads, no loads, very pixelated images. Unit claimed that I check my connections. But I have Verizon (Great Coverage and Speed) along with a very fast Router. In other words, "It's not me - It's you." This is not from a Ring Hater (I have the Alarm - It's great). Hopefully, I saved you some steps. Back it goes to Amazon.

author: JAL
content: I wanted to be able to see who was at my front door and talk to them. I bought the bundle with a free Echo Dot. Unfortunately, the Ring 2 Doorbell will not work with just audio through the Dot. It requires video AND audio to communicate with the Ring Doorbell. I think this is an oversight. A much more effective bundle would be the Ring 2 Doorbell and the Echo Show, which supports video AND audio. My Ring Doorbell is named Front Door. I simply ask Alexa Show to "Show the front door," and I can see who is at my front door and talk to them. They do not know if I am at home or connecting remotely. To turn off the camera, I say "Alexa, hide the front door." The reason this all works is that many doorbells have 24v power, so the camera is powered and ready to go with battery backup. Initially the Ring doorbell said that my wi fi connection was too weak. In actual practice my wifi connection to the Ring doorbell is fine. If your wifi connection IS truly too weak, consider extending your 2.4 wifi connection using a Rock Space Wi Fi Repeater. You should download the Amazon Alexa and Ring Apps to your phone. IF you purchase the Ring cloud option ($30/yr), you can  view motion detection videos on your phone using the Ring App. You use the Alexa app to link your Ring Doorbell to your Echo Show as a new "skill."

author: Olivia L.
content: The reason I bought this camera is it has rechargeable battery so I don't have to wire it outside the house. It is said the video resolution is 1080p but the resolution is much lower than the ones I got from the other camera with the same resolution, the ones from Ring must be 720 not 1080. The motion detected videos are recorded with the motion a few seconds after motion is detected so if it is a quick motion, you don't even see anything happened in the video. The ridiculous "feature" is you have to PAY for motion detected videos after free trial period, which is 2 months. Who does that!! Without motion detected videos, the camera is useless. I was thinking to return this but the return window in ONE month after you purchase it. product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Daniel W. Mccurdy
content: I've installed all sorts of WIFI and Z-Wave devices, and I have to admit I had a little trouble with this one. The main issues are the undisclosed installation details that you may find out that you need to know.  The "installation manual", such as it is, leaves much to the imagination in the name of simplicity.  There's not much more help on the website, and you really have to dig. The very first hiccup was that I could not complete the installation right after opening the box.  You have to charge the included battery first -- which took me more than 5 hours (it's rather potent).  So I had to interrupt my task and resume installation the following day.  Bummer. If you are wondering about why the unit needs a battery before it will work at all (even after wiring), you need to know that the device REPLACES your existing doorbell button and connects to the same two wires that were connected to that button;  however it also tries to get power from those same two wires.  Keeping in mind that the device also rings your existing chime by SHORTING those two wires together (just like the old button did), you will now understand why the battery is really there.  Yes, it allows the device to continue to operate during a power outage, but more importantly it also provides internal power whenever someone rings the doorbell because it has to short out its own external power feed for a few seconds to ring the old chime.  Clever design.  So the battery must be charged and installed prior to setup the first time.  Although the documentation does not say so, I am assuming that the device keeps the battery recharged thereafter, as long as it's connected to an existing chime (or a 16VAC transformer somewhere).  Of course the unit can operate wirelessly, but then you have to remove the battery periodically to recharge it.  Supposedly it will last a year. A second hiccup is the included DIODE, which may or may not have to be installed across the two connected wires depending on the TYPE of existing door chime you have.  If it's the old style mechanical type (ding-dong), you don't need (or want) the diode.  But if it's a digital type (the kind that plays a whole song for you), you need it.  And this is the point in time where you finally discover that the RING device is not compatible at all with many existing chime designs out there.  If you dig you will find lists of known-compatible mechanical and digital chimes, and it's a long list.  There are also lists of incompatible mechanical and digital chimes.  As long as these lists are, they are NOT complete.  In fact, I could find exactly ZERO chimes on either the mechanical or digital lists at my local big-box hardware stores.  I ended up settling for a mechanical chime that had a part number that was close to one on the compatible list, and fortunately it worked.  It seems to me that the RING folks should work harder making this part of the project go much more smoothly by providing better guidance on chime compatibility in the box.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Elsa
content: Buen producto puedo ver cada movimiento alrededor de mi casa aunque no esté ahí
title: Lo recomiendo muy útil

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: IslandStyle
content: I've had the Ring Video Doorbell 2 installed for one month, and here's how I'd rate some of the functionality: Motion Detection - 1.0 star For my use, this is the biggest challenge with the device.  I live close to the beach, and the breeze picks up every afternoon.  The movement from a plant about 6 feet from the camera triggers numerous false movement alerts due to a deficiency with the infrared detection.  Also, despite having the sensitivity set to ~25 feet, the motion recordings never start until someone walking up to my porch is within 8 feet with most recordings only starting when they are already on the porch or walking away from the porch.  A car pulling into my driveway will trigger an alert at ~15 feet. Security Camera - 3.0 stars The video quality is very clear, but because of the wide field of view there is a bit of fisheye effect.  Bottom line is this is great when someone is standing on your porch but the images 30 feet from the doorbell are too small.  Also, the night vision is okay but it seems like the porch light from my neighbor across the street (~150 feet) impacts my ability to see darker images in my yard. Video Doorbell - 4.5 stars For my use, this is where the unit excels as you can answer your doorbell from anywhere via the app.  I've only had one real experience with this, but it was nice to provide package delivery instructions to the carrier. Btw, this was a wired installation so I can't speak to the battery use.
title: If you can live with the motion detection shortfalls, this could be a good option for you

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: A. Watkins
content: I purchased two Ring Video Doorbell 2s during the Black Friday sale, I purchased 2 Echo Dots as well as a Chime Pro and two additional batteries. The items arrived in good condition, were easy to unbox, and the instructions and installion were straightforward. There was some trouble getting the 2nd doorbell to pair to the Chime but it was ultimately resolved. The guided setup was helpful and addressed common issues such as installing near a road or trees that will trigger motion capture. However, the app itself can be buggy. BUT the biggest issues are the complete lack of video recording unless you pay a monthly fee and the intermittent triggering of the motion detection. Set at the shortest range the motion sensor will trigger because the a car pulled into the driveway next door but doesn’t pick up a carrier delivering a package right in front of the door. Increasing the sensitivity only serves to kill the battery faster and cause notifications that you have no way to determine the cause.
title: Poor motion detection, no video recording without a monthly fee, terrible battery life

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Archer
content: Traded in my cell phone.  Tried to add the Ring app to my new phone and cant.  Ring customer service said while my email is on a Ring account, there's a gmail.com account listed as owning my Ring and they cant tell me the address.  We have tried everything and can't get access to the doorbell.  Ring said if we provided the purchase receipt they could maybe help.  That was 2 months ago and they've done nothing.  I have a 9 month old Ring doorbell that is useless now.  Buyer beware their customer service sucks.
title: Bad customer service means useless product

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: J. Jones
content: 2 Waited a few months before posting this review. I had high hopes for this RING DOORBELL 2, but was sadly disappointed. The Ring Doorbell 2 has a long lag tjme....it just spins then says connection lost. Our internet provider is not to blame. We purchase the Ring door bell wifi extender and it made zero difference. Now on to the quality of the Ring Doorbell 2 camera, it is a very neat design but there are many flaws. The Ring Doorbell 2 night vision is awful including the motion range. We cannot get it reach the end of our porch without fully extending the range into the street traffic. We have tried the enclosed Ring Doorbell 2 mounts with zero luck. I wish they would make updates to the Ring Doorbell camera for easier usage by customers.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: B. CAIN
content: It *might* take you five minutes to install the Ring (to screw it to the wall) but it will take you untold hours (and extra $$$) to try to resolve the Wifi issue. I live in a small townhouse. I have strong Wifi and a very good router with two bands. I never have any trouble with any other devices. But even after two setups, the Ring's connection to my Wifi is still "very weak," which means I usually can't see "motions" and "rings" until notifications that arrive much later -- if at all.  In fact, the wifi connection is weaker after the second setup. My research regarding this issue -- which seems to be common -- shows Ring and other users offering the following fixes: 1/ "move your router close to the doorbell" (because everyone is able to put a router by their front door) and 2/ buy a wifi booster or Ring Chime ($50) to boost its reach. And many users report that the boosters don't work. Ring makes it sound like you just charge this baby up and screw it to the wall and you're ready to go. HARDLY. It has been extremely frustrating, and I won't be recommending this to others, unless they are network experts. FYI: My neighbor has Nest and says he has not had these same issues. My brother is looking into the Arlo system, which is what I just recommended to someone who asked me how I like the Ring. ALSO -- the MOTION DETECTION is just puzzling. It will occasionally catch a car going by in the parking lot, which is fine. But when I pull into the space right in front of my door and get out and walk up the walkway to my door, it doesn't pick up any of that. It doesn't pick up anything until I'm right AT the doorbell. Yet, it'll get a car driving by even farther back. And yesterday someone came to my house and rang my regular doorbell (because the RING is TOO LARGE to fit where that is, so now I get to have TWO doorbells and charge this thing to keep it working) and I walked out and stood right in front of the Ring talking to her for at least two or three minutes, and NO ALERTS.  So I really don't get it...
title: Good luck getting a usable Wifi signal

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Tom4X2
content: Well that was easy. It’s not very often I find a product that installs right the first time. Ring made that happen, partly by including just about every conceivable item you might need to complete the installation of the doorbell and the app. Plus, the app works equally well on my iPhone and my iPad. I read through the instructions before I bought the Ring Doorbell 2 and watched the installation video, so I knew what to expect.  "Murphy’s Law" always comes into play for my projects though and sure enough when I went to place the Ring Doorbell 2 on the space where my old doorbell was, I found the trim molding on the door frame was about 1/8" higher on one side than the other. This would’ve affected the viewing angle whether or not I used either of the two included adapters to angle the Ring Doorbell 2 to either side or up or down a few degrees.  I found I needed a 1/8" shim to balance out the mounting.  I had an old paint stirring stick so I just used a 3" piece of the paint stirring stick to provide the 1/8" ‘fill’ and voila, problem solved. Other than that, the installation and configuration followed the instructions perfectly. I did find I had to adjust the "Motion" settings to keep the device from using too much power.  There are three "Motion Zones" and a "slider" to adjust the ‘motion field of coverage’.  My home faces a subdivision street about 50’ from the front door, so I adjusted the slider towards ‘Minimum’ so the Motion Detection covers the front yard, but not the street.  The camera still covers the street, it just isn’t triggered to record/alert except when a motion detection occurs within the narrowed range.  I also turned off the left and right Motion Zones.  Once I did this, the Power Consumption fell to an acceptable level.  Now the Ring Doorbell 2 should run 24x7 and never deplete the battery. I knew before I purchased the Ring Doorbell 2 that I would want Ring’s $3/month storage plan.  I just calculated that into to the overall purchase cost and feel it’s a reasonable charge for what you get.
title: Well that was easy, and works perfectly.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Dolmanet
content: UPDATE -  I started having problems with the battery after about 18 months.  The system kept showing low battery, even after I charged it overnight and the battery indicator showed that it was fully charged.  I love the Ring doorbell and we've gotten really used to having it, so I bought a replacement battery, but got the same low battery error from the system.  I didn't want to give up, so I uninstalled the system and reinstalled it from scratch (had to remove it from the door to scan the QR code), including connection to my Wifi network.  That did the trick!  So if you have battery problems, try that before buying a new battery. I got the package deal with the Ring Video Doorbell 2 and Alexa during the holiday 2018 season.  I waited awhile to write this review to check it against the complaints folks have in the 1-2 star reviews.  First, I agree that the Protect plan trial should last longer than 30 days, but for $36/year, it's well worth it and hard to justify the anger people express about it (YES, Ring should be more forthcoming with that fact!).  I mounted the Ring on my front door, just above the lock (make sure you have enough clearance under the ring to install/remove the battery AND access the screw head), about 4' off the ground.  I left the angle and sensitivity settings at default to see if created any of the 'false alarms' that other people complain about, and it has worked perfectly since installed.  It alarms when someone gets within about 15' of the door (e.g. mowing the front lawn) and it's never been triggered by cars passing on the street.  It's awesome to 'answer the door' when you're at work or even out of town.  Excellent product, well worth the cost, just plan on the extra annual cost for Ring Protect.
title: UPDATE - Awesome Product, but Pay for the Ring Protect Plan!

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Pharaoh KD
content: The wifi connection with the doorbell and other products is weak. The motion detection is far from reliable. The doorbell's camera/video shows people leaving the door after they have walked onto the property, up the steps, and have done whatever they came to do. I see the mailman, delivery guys, and others walking away. I don't even get to see their faces. The bell doesn't always chime my phone or the additional chime I purchased from Ring. This product is a great idea. The execution of this product leaves a lot to be desired. Did they consult with a tech manufacturer before putting this product to market? It's so close to being a good product though. But, no cigar. The Ring help pages tend to point to the other items connected to the product as being the problem. No. It's the doorbell that's the problem. When you experience problems, they suggest things like moving the placement of the Ring doorbell. That's laughable. They should be ashamed of themselves for suggesting something like that. The doorbell is placed where a doorbell would go. No one is going to move their doorbell. We can't move the entrance to our homes. Then they suggest moving the placement of the router. This is less offensive than the prior suggestion. But, it still not satisfactory. They don't know how many other things are connected to a person's  home routers. Moving it just for the Ring might not be a feasible option. In most cases, it is not. But, I think whoever came up with that so-called solution is very aware of that fact.  My cell phones and tablets get great wifi reception in the location where the ring is. To me, this points to the Ring has having sub-par internal wifi connection. I think they can do better. Unsatisfactory connection Low video quality Shuttering Video freeze No video Unsatisfactory motion detection Poor execution of tech product
title: Close But No Cigar

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: DisneyMom
content: We have ours hardwired to the house. For the first 30 days with the free trial it worked great. Now that it can no longer be returned and you have to pay the subscription fee to view footage it is awful! It either wont connect or gives me a black screen and I have to keep closing and reopening the app to get it to work, by then it's to late though. We have the cheapest subscription and I feel you probably have to pay the most expensive one to get it to work well again. I refuse to do that. I went back and forth getting this cause of the negative reviews and procrastinated for like a year but then just went for it. Should have just gone with my gut though and skipped it till things drastically changed. Wont buy any future products from anything to do with Ring.
title: Junk after 30 day trial

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Dezz
content: Speaker is horrible and cannot hear well. You have to have great connection to be able to answer or view. You also have to subscribe to a monthly fee service. Not worth it.
title: Not worth it

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: RANDY B DUNN
content: This thing has been nothing but trouble.  First of all it loses all of its settings when you take the battery out to recharge it (which I need to do once a month).  Second it has no range.  I had to buy a dedicated repeater and install it 3 feet from the thing just to get 'good' reception.  Even then video is about 1 frame/sec when it works, which is about 1 in ten rings from visitors.  Audio never works.  I have a 120mbps service at my house.  I like the idea, but the implementation is awful.  Going to round file it and get a hard line solution.  I have a $40 WiFi video camera at my house that works just fine.  Hmmm.... The fun continues.  Took a dump the other day, I tried to reconnect to the router and cannot get it to connect at all.  But my phone connects just fine and the router is about sitting on top of the darn ring. I tried moving the router farther away up to 8 feet or so, but the ring just cannot seem to connect.  Such an expensive device for this to happen.  I am hoping that some day they update the firmware to fix these bugs but so far nothing.
title: Great idea, terrible results, and it just seems to get worse over time.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: rhklzr
content: Camera - good. Installation - easy. Quality - for what I paid, it better be good - and it is. MY KNOCK on the ring - you HAVE to pay a monthly or yearly fee to view videos of motion.  There is no option other than that.  If you don't pay, you have nothing more than an expensive peep hole for your door.  Canary - I can at least see the videos for 24 hours.  BLINK - they are mine forever (no fee).  RING - get ready to pay.  Glad I just have the doorbell and nothing else - fees go up for multiple devices.  I can't believe that of all the reviews I read about the product, I don't remember seeing that anywhere.  Well, now you can read it and decide for yourself is RING is for you.  For me, I won't buy another RING product for that simple reason alone and it looks like they have some good products.
title: Good, BUT...

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: djla
content: Worked great for a while. Put an end to a lot of vandalism by neighborhood denizens.  Then Ring ran an update in April and my phone stopped connecting to WiFi and would only connect to Ring, even when I was out of range.  Not matter what I tried I got zero support and  Ring kept blaming my WiFi signal.  A month ago, after another update, I finally got it working again, after reinstalling the app altogether and starting anew.  Worked great until the last update two days again, and I'm back where I was, with Ring claiming it's my internet.  Nothing else has a problem.  I wish Ring was both more responsive and responsible.  $200 is a lot of money for something that has worked less than half the time I've had it. UPDATE: Got it working -- after removing most of the security features of my router.  App still stinks, though.  I can take up to three minutes for the list of event videos to load, over cell or WiFi doesn't matter.  Video skips and misses and sometimes doesn't work at all and fails to record. Still wouldn't buy it.
title: Good product ruined by bad updates

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Bradley C. Tohtz
content: I am beyond disappointed in this product.  It has been nothing but a headache and problems since it was installed several months ago.  Who knew a doorbell could be the source of such frustration.  Let me break down the problems with this shit product. 1. The motion detection feature on this device is horribly broken.  My house faces a street and it constantly gives false motion alerts to EVERY passing car.  I have tried updating the setting and tweaking the motion detection shit and nothing works.  It either detects nothing until someone is entering your home, or picks up everything that moves with 50ft of your house.  THERE IS NO IN BETWEEN. 2.  The battery needs to be CONSTANTLY replaced.  Who the hell wants a door bell that you have monitor every couple weeks to see if it needs to be charged.  Seriously, every 2 weeks the battery is dead.  If I turn off motion detection, we can stretch it to maybe a month before it dies, but what is the point of this thing if it doesn't show package thieves or who is on my property. 3.  My wifi router is no more than 15ft away from my front door, its in a wide open room and the signal easily stretches out to my back yard (50-85ft) with full bars.  Yet this device drops the wifi signal weekly and then it no longer works at all until you take it apart. I can't handle this piece of shit anymore and wish nothing more than to have never purchased this in the first place.  This product is nothing but a torture device disguised as a video doorbell.  Being forced to use this for another month and I might kill myself.
title: Such a crap product.  If you like headaches, ignore this review

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Latch001
content: I've only had the Ring 2 Doorbell for about 3 months and it does a great job at getting cars that drive by, but if someone actually comes up to the door, it only gets them leaving, and on top of that, it only works about half the time. This was a complete waste of money and I would suggest going with a different brand such as Nest. I bought the Ring 2 Doorbell and the Ring Floodlight w/camera, they are both pieces of garbage and a complete waste of about $400. Learn from those of us that have left these reviews, the doorbell is really only good for people that actually ring the doorbell! It's pretty much worthless to get someone walking up the steps to the actual door. Update: 03/13/2020 This thing still sucks! It only works about 30% of the time. I have it angled down my steps towards the street where my car is parked. My car got broken into last night around 1:30 in the morning (I know this because my neighbor has real cameras and caught people breaking into cars in front of his house at 1:38), the doorbell camera didn’t capture anything, as usual! It bever works when it would be prudent. I would still accept a full refund if Ring wants to give me my money back.
title: Pretty much worthless... Still!

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Anthony R. Crain
content: You can use ring without a plan, but the motion sensor part becomes worthless. The doorbell feature is still useful. I thought they would give you a couple of weeks of video for free, or three days or at least the most recent action. Without a plan, my motion sensor chimes. But by the time it launches there is nothing to see and I can't even rewind the few seconds that have passed to see what set it off. Worthless. Also often it says it's having trouble connecting, then nothing. Finally it shows the new video in my history and of course, I can't view it! Worthless without one of the plans. Also, the length of the video seems too short. There is still motion, but the camera stops recording. And if events happen close together, they are ignored. Many times, when I leave, the sensor doesn't chime. I feel like a ghost! I haven't decided it I will pay the $30 / year, but as of now, I wish I hadn't bought this thing.
title: Be ready to pay $30 or $100 / year.

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Kris
content: 1 st Ring 2 Door Bell apparently DOA, 2 hours + 1 with Ring Support, I decided it was dead Ring support wanted to keep trying. Could not find Wireless Network. 2nd Ring 2 Door Bell 2 hours, it did find Wireless Network 1st time, yet will connect to phone correctly. Support person's shift was over and we will try tomorrow. I will update my experiences after tomorrow. Well, here we go another Ring Fail. I have upgraded to the Ring Pro Serious Fail. 1st Ring 2 was DOA took 3 hours with support and they were not willing to agree that it was DOA. 2nd Ring 2 was also a fail it would work intermittently yet way too many false alerts. 1st and last Ring Pro over an hour to install, missing parts and wrong installation tool for the screws. Took over an hour to install. Total time with Ring Support over 10 hours, total time installing then removing 3 units 12 hours and it still has way too many false alerts. looking for an alternate solution. If I did not have so many holes in my siding I would just put back the old doorbell and buy a security camera that does not require a subscription. The Ring App crashes 30-40% of the time, just locks up. They keep bringing out updates yet none of them works consistently. Customer service people are nice yet uninformed and have no real solutions for these POS devices. Do yourself a favor and buy anything else, these products are not ready to ship. Well, another 1.5 hours last hour with Ring Support. Another fail, the current recommendation is to try a different phone. Apparently, both of my androids Moto's don't work. Not ready for prime time as my 2 phones have the latest software, fully charged batteries and I have a very strong 2.4 network, which is running fine. Replaced battery and finally got it to work another hour with customer support bringing total hours to 6.5 hours to install. I finally tried a new battery and everything works now. Unfortunately, Customer support is nice yet of limited use with such a poor quality product, if you get one that works and will install right out of the box great, for the rest of us. I suggest moving on. Choose Wisely! Due to the problems I have, I would recommend any different brand, Ring App crashes, Website is poor, Troubleshooting is a joke. If I had read a review like this I would have bought a different product.
title: 1st one DOA 2nd One fails to work consistnetly now on a Ring Pro which is another

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: ELF
content: Bought these after testing out some cloud cams from Amazon and after having heard of its acquisition by Amazon. On the exact same place cloud cams work flawlessly and this is an absolute waste of money. Doesn't register most of the times and takes forever to access. After installing it when I receive a notification I open cloud cam instead of Ring. Support will give you the standard vanilla procedures and is also a disappointment. product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: CiCi
content: BEWARE:  DO NOT BUY UNLESS YOU’RE READY TO PAY FOR SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE.  Ring’s new policy renders this device essentially useless unless you pay up for a subscription service ($30/year for 1 ring or $100/yr for multiple rings). None of this was clearly detailed in the product box on Ring’s new policy. We’ve had a ring for years and never subscribed for long term video storage.  We used to be able to see at least 24 hours of video footage from ring for free, which was enough time.  We recently added a new Ring, and all was working fine initially as the new device comes with a trail subscription for 30 days. Well, Ring’s new policy is ZERO video footage available to view unless you subscribe.  Without a subscription, it’s now an expensive electronic doorbell!  You can view LIVE video (which burns the battery down much quicker) and technically, if someone rings the doorbell, you can see the “current” video and use intercom with them.  Per Ring’s settings,  “current view” is within seconds of someone pressing ring.  Which means if you didn’t immediately go to the app, the video becomes a “past footage” and without a subscription, not avaiable for view! This is total BS and clearly designed to force you to pay for the subscription service.  I am so disappointed with this company and attempt to extort money from customers.  I’m feel duped out of $199 for a useless device!  I’m abandoning Ring.  Going to find an alternative.
title: BEWARE:  USELESS UNLESS YOU PAY EXTRA FOR SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Susan in DC
content: These devices were never designed to be used in very cold weather.  I had one that was hardwired so I wouldn't have to worry about recharging batteries.  After outdoor temperatures dropped into the teens and single digits, it stopped drawing current from the hardware and started draining the battery.  It never reconnected to the hardwire as it was supposed to, even after spending hours on the phone with customer support and trying every troubleshooting option under the sun.  I finally changed to a Ring Video Doorbell Pro, which is hardwired only and has no batteries.  Let's hope this one works better. Also, the motion sensor never seemed to work properly, taking videos of nothing moving or cars driving down the street (despite frequent adjustments to sensitivity to fix this) and missing other very important things, like whoever it was that abandoned a car in front of my house more than a month ago.  Best I could do with that one was estimate based on other videos showing when the car was not there and where it was.
title: Stops working in very cold weather; erratic motion sensor

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Paul
content: There are 3 things making me write this review with 1 star: 1. Customer Support 2. Quality 3. Required Subscription plan First, I set this up, video looked great, did decent job at motion detection (does not have people detection like many other security cameras).  However, two way voice communication was horrible.  The doorbell sits 15 feet from my router, I have not other issues with any other 2 way vioice systems (Wyze cameras, Brink, Amazon Cloud Cam) nor Alexa video chat or FaceTime.  I contacted Ring support, and they sent me an 8 step try this than that list of stuff.  I stated it would take an exorbitant amount of time to complete, but they just said I needed to go through all of the steps (reinstall apps, reset doorbell, turn off bluetooth, hotspot wifi, etc, etc) in order for them to support me.  Not a very customer obsessed response. Then, I started getting notifications about having to subscribe to their "Ring Protect" service, to get online recordings.  For $200, I would think this would be included ... it is in my Blink XT2 (another Amazon product) and my $25 Wyze Camera! For the money, just get a $25 Wyze camera, have it Alert on sounds (doorbells send notifications) and then you can 2 way audio through it.
title: VERY DISAPPOINTED ... Thought Amazon would make this a great product :-(

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: RC
content: I am very disappointed with this product. When I attempt to check in with my phone most of the time the camera will not display it continues to loop as if it’s trying to turn on.  When you finally get the view the person would be gone. Great concept but it does not work well.
title: Disappointed

product: Ring Video Doorbell 2 with HD Video, Motion Activated Alerts, Easy Installation
author: Five Digits
content: A couple of things warrant the 3 star rating. We initially purchased and returned the Pro version.
